details.title: Reliability models of a bridge system structure under incomplete information
details.standardTitle: Reliability models of a bridge system structure under incomplete information

p: Yue Song received the B.S., and M.S. degrees in probability and statistics from Northwest University, Xi'an in 1991, and 1994 respectively. She is currently an associate professor of applied mathematics at XiDian University, and working on the Ph.D. degree in applied mathematics at XiDian University. Her doctoral research is focused on system reliability, and network optimization.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Appl. Math., Xidian Univ., Xi'an, China
authors.name: Yue Song

p: Hai-lin Feng received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Yan'an University; and the M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in applied mathematics from XiDian University, Xi'an in 1991, and 2004 respectively. She is currently an associate professor of applied mathematics at Xidian University, and actively engaged in network reliability and stochastic optimization.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Appl. Math., Xidian Univ., Xi'an, China
authors.name: Hai-lin Feng

p: San-yang Liu received the M.S. degree in applied mathematics from XiDian University, and the Ph.D. degree in computational mathematics from Xi'an Jiao tong University, Xi, an in 1984, and 1989 respectively. After finishing the Ph.D. degree, he spent one year at the University Paul Sabatier, Toulouse, France as a postdoctoral fellow. He is currently a professor of applied mathematics at XiDian University. His research interests include nonlinear optimization, combinatorial optimization, network optimization, and system reliability.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Appl. Math., Xidian Univ., Xi'an, China
authors.name: San-yang Liu

details.abstract: Most methods of system reliability analysis assume that the precise probability distributions of the component lifetime to failure are available, and the system components are independent. However this assumption may be unreasonable in a wide scope of cases. Therefore, imprecise reliability modes of a bridge system structure are put forward in this paper, for cases when the above assumptions are violated. The analysis is based on only some partial information about the component lifetime distributions including points of unknown distributions, and probabilities on nested intervals. The effect of the component independence condition on the reliability of systems is studied. The formulas of the unreliability of the bridge system structure are obtained in the explicit form under different conditions.

context.text: To cope with this problem, the theory of imprecise probabilities (also called the theory of lower previsions [1], the theory of interval statistical models [2], or the theory of interval probabilities [3]) is increasingly regarded as a promising tool to assess the reliability of systems.
The foundation of imprecise probability theory can be found in [1], [2].
In this paper, we use the notations and definitions introduced by Wally [1].

references.title: Statistical Reasoning With Imprecise Probabilities
references.text: P. Walley, Statistical Reasoning With Imprecise Probabilities, 1991, Chapman and Hall.

links.abstract: Network reliability analysis is usually based on minimal path or cut enumeration from which the associated reliability expressions are deduced. The cut-set method is a popular approach in the reliability analysis of many systems from simple to complex configurations. The computational requirements necessary to determine the minimal cut-sets of a network depend mainly on the number of minimal paths between the source and the sink. A technique designated as the "Path Tracing Algorithm" is presente...

context.text: Most methods are based on conventional reliability theory [10]–[12].

links.abstract: Systems with two failure modes (STFM) consist of devices, which can fail in either of two modes. For example, switching systems can not only fail to close when commanded to close but can also fail to open when commanded to open. This paper considers systems consisting of different elements characterized by nominal performance level in each mode. Such systems are multi-state because they have multiple performance levels in both modes, depending on the combination of elements available at the mome...

context.text: Most methods are based on conventional reliability theory [10]–[11][12].

two failure-modes
references.text: G. Levitin, "Reliability of multi-state systems with two failure-modes", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 52, pp. 340-348, 2003.

links.abstract: Calculating system-reliability via the knowledge of structure function is not new. However, such attempts have had to compromise with the increasing complexity of a system. This paper overcomes this problem through a new representation of the structure function, and demonstrates that the well-known systems considered in the state-of-art follow this new representation. With this new representation, the important reliability calculations, such as Birnbaum reliability-importance, become simple. The...
